sentences.text: This paper presents a critical discussion of the various approaches that have been used in the evaluation of Natural Language systems .
We conclude that previous approaches have neglected to evaluate systems in the context of their use , e.g. solving a task requiring data retrieval .
This raises questions about the validity of such approaches .
In the second half of the paper , we report a laboratory study using the Wizard of Oz technique to identify NL requirements for carrying out this task .
We evaluate the demands that task dialogues collected using this technique , place upon a prototype Natural Language system .

We identify three important requirements which arose from the task that we gave our subjects : operators specific to the task of database access , complex contextual reference and reference to the structure of the information source .
We discuss how these might be satisfied by future Natural Language systems .

kg2text: The Wizard of Oz technique was used to identify three important requirements that arose from giving subjects tasks requiring data retrieval, such as database access. These NL requirements have a broader term, Natural Language systems, which require operators specific to the task and complex contextual reference. The second half of this paper reports on these findings. In contrast, previous approaches in evaluating Natural Language systems have neglected to evaluate them in the context of their use, e.g., solving tasks requiring data retrieval. Future Natural Language systems will potentially satisfy requirements for solving such tasks.

In this study, we evaluated the demands that task dialogues collected using this technique place upon a prototype Natural Language system. Our analysis revealed NL requirements for carrying out tasks such as data retrieval, including complex contextual references and operators specific to database access. These findings highlight the need for systems to understand and navigate complex information structures. In contrast to previous approaches, our study has neglected to evaluate these demands on existing systems. Instead, we focused on identifying NL requirements that can inform the development of more effective Natural Language processing technologies.
